claim: If you're running focal fossa, you're using linux.

supporting.text: Focal Fossa is the codename for Ubuntu 20.04 LTS, which is a well-known Linux distribution.

attacks.text: Focal Fossa is the codename for Ubuntu 20.04 LTS, which is a well-known Linux distribution.
Some users may run Ubuntu 20.04 LTS in a virtual machine or container without directly using Linux as the host OS.
Even in virtualized environments, the guest OS (Ubuntu 20.04 LTS) is still Linux, so the claim holds.
The term 'using Linux' is ambiguous - it could refer to interacting with Linux as an end-user or merely having it installed.
Common usage of 'using Linux' implies the OS is actively being used, which is true for Ubuntu 20.04 LTS installations.

supporting.text: Ubuntu, including its Focal Fossa release, is built on the Linux kernel, which is the core component of all Linux-based operating systems.

attacks.text: Ubuntu, including its Focal Fossa release, is built on the Linux kernel, which is the core component of all Linux-based operating systems.
Some users may run Focal Fossa in a container or virtual machine with a non-Linux host OS, meaning they are not directly using Linux.
Containers and VMs still rely on the Linux kernel for Focal Fossa's operation, even if the host OS is different.
The claim implies direct usage, but many Focal Fossa users interact only with application layers, unaware they're using Linux.
Technical unawareness doesn't change the underlying OS architecture, which remains Linux-based.

supporting.text: The term 'Linux' is commonly used to refer to operating systems that use the Linux kernel, and Ubuntu Focal Fossa fits this definition.

attacks.text: The term 'Linux' is commonly used to refer to operating systems that use the Linux kernel, and Ubuntu Focal Fossa fits this definition.
Some users may run Ubuntu Focal Fossa in a virtual machine or container without realizing it uses the Linux kernel, thus not associating it with Linux.
The term 'Linux' is sometimes contested as inaccurate for GNU/Linux distributions like Ubuntu, which include many non-Linux components.
The GNU Project explicitly argues that calling such systems 'Linux' overlooks the contributions of GNU software.
Corporate environments might brand their Ubuntu installations without mentioning Linux, creating user confusion.
Technical documentation and Ubuntu's own website consistently reference its Linux foundation, making corporate branding exceptions rare.

supporting.text: Official documentation and support channels for Ubuntu Focal Fossa explicitly state that it is a Linux distribution.

attacks.text: Official documentation and support channels for Ubuntu Focal Fossa explicitly state that it is a Linux distribution.
Some users may be running Ubuntu Focal Fossa in a virtualized environment that does not use the Linux kernel, such as WSL (Windows Subsystem for Linux).
WSL still relies on the Linux kernel, even if it is virtualized, so the original argument holds.
The term 'Linux distribution' is sometimes used loosely, and some variants of Ubuntu may include non-Linux kernels in experimental builds.
Official Ubuntu Focal Fossa releases are exclusively Linux-based, and experimental builds are not considered standard.

supporting.text: Software packages and tools available in Focal Fossa are designed to work with the Linux kernel, further confirming its Linux-based nature.

attacks.text: Software packages and tools available in Focal Fossa are designed to work with the Linux kernel, further confirming its Linux-based nature.
Focal Fossa could theoretically be modified to run on a different kernel, though this is uncommon.
Some packages in Focal Fossa may work with compatibility layers like WSL on Windows, without requiring native Linux.
Compatibility layers like WSL still ultimately rely on the Linux kernel for functionality.

supporting.text: The Ubuntu community and Canonical, the company behind Ubuntu, consistently refer to Focal Fossa as a Linux distribution in all public communications.

attacks.text: The Ubuntu community and Canonical, the company behind Ubuntu, consistently refer to Focal Fossa as a Linux distribution in all public communications.
Some users might run Focal Fossa in a non-Linux environment using compatibility layers or virtualization, such as WSL (Windows Subsystem for Linux).
WSL and similar compatibility layers still rely on the Linux kernel, so the underlying system is technically Linux.
Canonical's branding might not reflect technical accuracy, as marketing materials sometimes oversimplify technical details.
Technical documentation from Canonical and Ubuntu explicitly states that Focal Fossa is based on the Linux kernel.
